item.title: Ticket #129 (Need to change 1-letter codes in calendar with 2-letter codes in order ...) created
item.dc:creator: donpaolo
item.description:
The english 1-letter codes for week days are S M T W T F S

There are 2 couples: the S's and the T's

In other languages it's not so.

Need to put a smaller 2-letter code with no ambiguity:

Su Mo Tu We Th Fr Sa

so that you could translate well.

item.title: Ticket #128 (Need Delete All or Comment Flood protection) created
item.dc:creator: anonymousbugger
item.description:
I currently use comment moderation in my implementation of WordPress and I think it worked wonderfully.

Except when I get comment flooded. It takes forever to go through and select delete for each comment. In those cases, instead of using Wordpress, I use MySQL to delete.

If not already in place, I suggest some sort of comment flood protection combined with a function to delete all comments listed.

item.title: Ticket #16 (WP should use HTTP headers instead of the META element) updated
item.dc:creator: Anne
item.description: That isn't the advantage of HTTP-EQUIV and it never was. When a file is saved character information can be added by using BOM.

item.title: Ticket #32 (Calendar makes no use of option "start_of_week") updated
item.dc:creator: Anne
item.description: Probably not, this bug hasn't been assigned yet.

item.title: Ticket #113 (Post content 'lost' if multiple <!--more--> (more...) tags used.) updated
item.dc:creator: tormodh
item.description:
Yes, I agree with that. My thought was in the direction of userfriendly-ness. In case any user by any reason, or without reason, adds an extra <!--more--> somewhere - any content after the second <!--more--> won't show.

Um. My reasoning is that if <!--more--> is not to be used more than once, $content shouldn't be split into more than two parts, or all subsequent parts of $content needs to be set back together.

item.title: Ticket #127 (need to stop spitting warnings in browser) created
item.dc:creator: donpaolo
item.description:
I'm using wordpress on a windows server. php is set so that it spits the warnings to the browser.

The warnings due to not existing language page interfere with the installation code and with other pages.

It's necessary to stop them from beeing exited to the browser.

The code

<?php ini_set('display_errors', "0"); ?>

at the top of the files that could give a warning resolves all.

item.title: Ticket #113 (Post content 'lost' if multiple <!--more--> (more...) tags used.) updated
item.dc:creator: mark
item.description: <!--more--> is suppose to be used only once (as far as I know and makes sense to me). For more pages, you should use <!--nextpage-->.

item.title: Ticket #124 ("Publish" button is redunant and confusing.) updated
item.dc:creator: mark
item.description: The publish button does exactly what it says: "Publish". If you were to click on the "publish" radio button then click save that would be an extra, unnecessary step. Publish is there as a button because it is the most commonly used. I realized this the first time I used WP (1.01). If you want to store something as private, you click the private radio button then click save.

item.title: Ticket #126 (the_category produces Database SQL error and a warning) updated

item.description: Call the_category with or without parameters.

item.title: Ticket #126 (the_category produces Database SQL error and a warning) created

The below error is reached when calling the_category with or without any paremeters. It is not called inside the loop, but is called from with a plugin for WordPress called breadcrumb:

Database error: [You have an error in your SQL syntax near at line 9] SELECT category_id, cat_name, category_nicename, category_description, category_parent FROM wp_newscategories, wp_newspost2cat WHERE wp_newspost2cat.category_id = cat_ID AND wp_newspost2cat.post_id =

Warning: Invalid argument supplied for foreach() in /mnt/web_g/d24/s42/b01e1b28/www/wordpress/wp-includes/template-functions-category.php on line 139

item.title: Ticket #125 (problem with timestamps when blog timezone and server timezone differ) updated
item.dc:creator: anonymousbugger
item.description:
The problem could be temporarily resolved (at least with reference to gnome-blog) commenting out line 1303

$post_date_gmt = get_gmt_from_date(date('Y-m-d H:i:s', $dateCreated));

in the function mwnewpost of the / metaWeblog API /

item.title: Ticket #125 (problem with timestamps when blog timezone and server timezone differ) updated
item.dc:creator: donpaolo
item.description: the post_date_gmt field gets right if I edit the post, set the edit timestamp flag and save.

item.title: Ticket #125 (problem with timestamps when blog timezone and server timezone differ) created
item.dc:creator: donpaolo
item.description:
I work in a country with timezone=-4, and I put this value in my user options.

However, the server where the blog runs has timezone=+2.

When I post a messagge, it doesn't appear in the main page, if I post it with gnome-blog (metaweblog API).

Examining the database with phpMyAdmin, I see that the field post_date_gmt isn't correct: instead of showing 8:43, it shows 18:43. Hence the post, though appears published, isn't show in the main page.

It could be because of a incorrect management of timezones: instead of calculating

post_date_gmt = [server_post_time] - [+2 (server t/z)] + [-4 (blog t/z)] = post_time - 6

supposedly it calculates

post_date_gmt = [server_post_time] + [+2 (server t/z)] - [-4 (blog t/z)] = post_time + 6

I saw that the problems appear in the same form if I change my wordpress user timezone. I checked it with -3, -5, -6, -9, etc.

It could be a problem in the metaweblog API.
